title: Ivan Medek
text:
Ivan Medek (July 13, 1925 – January 6, 2010) was a Czech classical music critic, radio broadcaster and journalist. Medek was an important voice of the Czech <a href="anti-communist">anti-communist</a> opposition movement, particularly after being forced into <a href="exile">exile</a> from <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> in 1978. Medek collaborated closely with such Czechoslovak politicians as <a href="V%C3%A1clav%20Havel">Václav Havel</a> and <a href="Pavel%20Tigrid">Pavel Tigrid</a> in opposition to communist rule.
He was a brother of the Czech painter <a href="Mikul%C3%A1%C5%A1%20Medek">Mikuláš Medek</a> and the son of the general <a href="Rudolf%20Medek">Rudolf Medek</a>. 
Medek was born in <a href="Prague">Prague</a>, <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a>, on July 13, 1925. He began his career as both a classical music critic and journalist. He worked as a musician for the <a href="Czech%20Philharmonic">Czech Philharmonic</a> until he was fired by the government for his support of the opposition.
Medek was an original signatory of the <a href="Charter%2077">Charter 77</a> <a href="manifesto">manifesto</a> in 1977. Persecution by the communist government for his participation in Charter 77 forced Medek into <a href="exile">exile</a> in neighboring <a href="Austria">Austria</a> beginning in 1978. Medek began working at the <a href="Voice%20of%20America">Voice of America</a> in Austria, where he broadcast <a href="news">news</a> and information into <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a>. His VoA radio broadcasts became an important link for anti-communist <a href="dissidents">dissidents</a> in his native Czechoslovakia.
Medek returned to Czechoslovakia from exile in 1989 during the <a href="Velvet%20Revolution">Velvet Revolution</a>. In 1993, Medek was appointed to the office of the presidency under <a href="V%C3%A1clav%20Havel">Václav Havel</a>, the first president of the <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>. He later became the head of the presidency, or chancellor, under Havel.
Medek died in <a href="Prague">Prague</a> on January 6, 2010, at the age of 84. He was survived by his wife, Helena.
